In  preparing  any  country  program  or  strategy,  financing  any  project,  or  by  making  any 
designation of or reference to a particular territory or geographic area in this document, the 
Asian Development Bank does not intend to make any judgments as to the legal or other status 
of any territory or area.

I.  INTRODUCTION 
 
1.  The Second Small and Medium-Sized Enterprises Development Program,1 approved by 
the Board of Directors of the Asian Development Bank (ADB) in October 2010, seeks to assist 
sustainable  high  economic  growth  in  Viet  Nam  by  supporting  the  development  and 
competitiveness of small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs).2 In the context of the regular 
loan  reviews  conducted,  the  Government  of  Viet  Nam  has  requested  additional  technical 
assistance  (TA)  for  the  implementation  of  several  remaining  key  milestones  and  triggers 
included in the policy matrix for subprogram 2 of the program. The proposed policy and advisory 
TA will also identify future avenues for ADB support to SME development in Viet Nam, in line 
with the country’s SME Development Plan, 2011–2015. The scope, expected impact, outcome 
and outputs, and implementation arrangements were agreed during a loan review and TA fact- 
finding mission in March 2012.3 The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1. 
 
II.  ISSUES 
 
2.   Healthy levels of private investment will continue to be essential to achieve the 7%–8% 
economic annual growth rate and the 8 million new jobs targeted under Viet Nam’s Socio-
Economic Development Strategy, 2011–2020. Increasingly, such contribution is expected to 
come  from  the  domestic  private  sector,  which  is  largely  composed  of  SMEs.  Since  the 
implementation of the Enterprise Law, 2005,4 the Government of Viet Nam has greatly assisted 
the development of SMEs with the establishment of a regulatory framework conducive to private 
enterprise. As a result, by the end of 2010, nearly 550,000 enterprises were registered in 
Viet Nam, up from 14,500 in 2000. SMEs represented 97% of the country’s total number of firms 
and 46% of gross domestic product. The domestic private sector accounted for 59% of total 
employment in 2010, up from 29% in 2000.  The growth in the number of private companies has 
been followed by sustained increases in the average dimension and productivity of the firms. 
From 2000 to 2010, the average capital per firm has increased six-fold, and the average net 
revenue per employee has tripled. However, the average SME size remains quite small at 
22 employees per enterprise and average capital of D17.6 billion.5 The contribution of SMEs to 
tax revenue is increasingly important. By the end of 2010, of the 336,000 enterprises paying 
taxes in Viet Nam, 318,000 were private enterprises, 13,000 were foreign-owned enterprises, 
and about 5,000 were state-owned enterprises (SOEs). 
 
3.   Untapped potential. Despite recent progress, SMEs’ potential to generate economic 
growth  and  create  employment  opportunities  is  still  largely  untapped.  This  stems  from  a 
combination  of  factors,  including  limited  access  to  finance,  an  incomplete  regulatory  and 
competition policy framework for SME development, and inefficient access to legal services. 
The TA will address aspects of these larger challenges, essential for the accomplishment of the 
proposed triggers and milestones of subprogram 2 of the program. 
 
4.   SME development is a key pillar of the government’s new Socioeconomic Development 
Strategy, 2011–2020, and the Socio-economic Development Plan, 2011–2015. SME growth

remains critical to overcome the structural growth limitations created by the predominance of 
SOEs in Viet Nam. SOEs capture a priority share of public financial resources for investment, 
despite evidence of low returns on capital and modest employment creation. SMEs can play a 
key role in improving economic efficiency and sustaining high productivity levels. Realization of 
SMEs’ potential for employment creation requires widening their access to finance and land, 
and improving the regulatory framework for their operations. Viet Nam’s economic growth will 
increasingly hinge on the capacity of SMEs to boost their competitiveness and carve out a role 
as trusted suppliers in international production chains. 
 
5.   Weak policy and regulatory framework. The policy and regulatory framework for SME 
development will require the implementation of the second Small and Medium-Sized Enterprises 
Development Plan, 2011–2015. The sector’s shortage of data, specifically sex-disaggregated 
data,  has  prevented  the  formulation  of  gender-sensitive  SME  development  strategies.  In 
addition, participatory processes for policy formulation have only recently been implemented 
and will require further review and effort. Critical pieces of the regulatory framework for private 
sector development, such as the Enterprise Law, 2005 and the Competition Law, 2004, are 
undergoing substantial review to incorporate missing aspects and to close legal loopholes.   
 
6.   Inadequate access to finance. In spite of recent progress in the reduction of interest 
rates  by  commercial  banks,  access to finance  remains a  long-standing  limitation for  SME 
development. After initial progress, the implementation of viable and sustainable market-based 
credit guarantee systems is still at the early stages. SMEs have limited access to conventional 
bank lending6 and face a shortage of alternative financial services. Because of their generally 
small size and lower sophistication, SMEs face important constraints in accessing both debt and 
equity financing. The sector also lacks specialized financing instruments for SMEs that provide 
incentives to investment in the managerial skills and the information and technological base of 
SMEs in Viet Nam. The approval of the SME Fund in March 2012 may provide such an 
instrument, but its operating guidelines still need to be developed.7  
 
7.  Poor access to legal support and protection. A recent study8 underlines the growing 
concern of the domestic business community about a perceived lack of access to legal services, 
which extends from access to legal texts to more specialized consultations. The implementation 
of Decree 66/2008 on Legal Support to Enterprises is progressing slowly. In particular, the 
newly created department at the Ministry of Justice in support of SME legal services lacks 
strategic focus, and it is likely largely underfunded for the important demands on its staff. 
 
8.   Cumbersome administrative procedures. SME development continues to be affected 
by a large number of administrative procedures that increase companies’ compliance costs and 
deter new start-ups. These procedures include cumbersome customs requirements that delay 
the  release  of  imported  goods  and  alter  production  processes.  Permanent  institutional 
mechanisms to control and simplify administrative procedures for SMEs are required. Improving 
SMEs’ competitiveness will require conducting regulatory impact assessments of new legal 
documents affecting SME development and operations.  
 
9.   Implementation Progress under the SMEDP. Despite adequate progress towards the 
implementation of the set of policy triggers and milestones incorporated in the policy matrix,

substantive work remains to complete key tasks in several of the main outputs. The TA will 
support both the implementation of remaining reform milestones under subprogram 2 of ADB’s 
Proposed Second SME Development Program, and of the post-program partnership framework. 
The TA will also open new ground for future ADB financial assistance in several areas, such as 
the potential for public–private partnerships for SMEs, or the provision of legal support services 
to SMEs. Beyond subprogram 2, additional financial support to SME development in Viet Nam 
might be better articulated along more specific challenges (e.g., legal support or support to land 
reform) rather than through comprehensive upstream policy-based lending programs. 
 
10.   Lessons. ADB has directly assisted the government’s efforts on SME development 
through a combination of policy-based cluster loans and TA.9 An important lesson learned by 
ADB is that SME development will largely be affected by a series of parallel reforms in the 
country’s financial and economic structure. ADB has been supporting Viet Nam’s economic 
reforms through programs aimed at SOE restructuring, microfinance industry development, and 
financial sector reform that are likely to have an important effect on private sector development. 
ADB’s draft country partnership strategy, 2012–2015 and the country operations business plan, 
2012–201410 specify private sector development as a key priority for sustainable and inclusive 
economic  growth.  Continued  support  to  reforms  and  engagement  has  also  shown  to  be 
essential to assist progress in the sector. ADB loans have been processed as clusters to ensure 
a medium-term focus, while reforms have been consistently assisted by high-level TA. The TA 
will include an innovative approach to assisting Viet Nam’s private sector development, while 
building on lessons from earlier initiatives.  
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
 
11.  The  impact  of  the  TA  will  be  a  business  environment  that  supports  greater  SME 
competitiveness. The outcome will be the implementation of key measures under the policy 
matrix for the program, and of strategic initiatives identified in the post program partnership 
framework. An expanding SME sector will generate more and better jobs, and contribute to 
sustainable poverty reduction. 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
 
12.  Core  result  area  1:  Enhancement  of  the  regulatory  framework  for  private 
enterprises in Viet Nam. Major activities in this area will comprise advisory assistance to the 
review  of  the  Enterprise  Law,  2005,  including  the  integration  of  provisions  on  corporate 
governance and mergers and acquisitions into the law, which undergoes its second major 
review since approval in 1999. Assistance will also be provided for the preparation of the 
required regulatory impact assessment (RIA) on the amended law. The RIA will be developed 
on the basis of government guidelines for such assessments, which were completed in 2012 
with ADB assistance.

13.   Core result area 2: Strengthening the framework for competition policy. Activities 
under this component include assisting the institutional development of the SME Legal Support 
Department of the Ministry of Justice with best international practices. The department will play 
an essential role in facilitating improved access to legal services for SMEs in Viet Nam. Private 
sector representatives have identified this issue as a key policy priority. It has, additionally, been 
highlighted as a key strategic initiative under the post program partnership framework (P3F), 
and an area for potential ADB support in the future. The TA will help identify the role of the 
department and the definition of its strategic plan. In addition, the TA will support the upgrading 
of the SME portal to help SMEs access legal documents—a long-standing concern of the 
business community; this will be coordinated with the Ministry of Planning and Investment (MPI) 
SME portal work. 
 
14.   The  TA  will  support  the  review  of  the  Competition  Law  and  the  preparation  of  its 
associated RIA. The review of the Competition Law is in its final stages and amendments are 
being  considered  to  the  law  and  its  implementing  regulations  that  will  require  an  impact 
assessment. 
 
15.   Core  result  area  3:  Improving  access  to  finance  for  small  and  medium-sized 
enterprises.  This  will  be  achieved  by  upgrading  the  SME  portal  to  produce  relevant  and 
regularly  updated  information  on  supply  and  demand  for  financial  services  for  SMEs.  An 
important addition to be supported by the TA is the preparation of a self-assessment tool for 
SMEs that would assist their dealings with financial institutions when accessing loans. 
 
16.   As an innovative aspect of ADB assistance to SME development, the TA will provide 
advisory assistance for exploring the potential of public–private partnerships (PPPs) for SMEs 
as an alternative strategy to leverage investment funds. This knowledge product will include 
(i) an assessment of Viet Nam’s regulatory framework for PPPs, and benchmark it with best 
international practices; (ii) the identification of sector potential for the development of PPPs with 
SME  participation;  and  (iii)  outlining  proposals  for  the  implementation  of  the  policy 
recommendations. As in the case of the assistance provided to the development of systems for 
the provision of legal support to SMEs, this initiative addresses a critical aspect of the P3F, and 
opens up new ground for future ADB involvement in this critical area of reform. The TA will also 
support the drafting of operational guidelines for the SME development fund—a new financing 
mechanism for SMEs managed by the MPI. The major outputs and activities are summarized in 
the table.

17.   Successful implementation of the TA will require the government to stay on course with 
key  macroeconomic  reforms  and  business  regulatory  reforms.  In  addition,  adequate 
coordination among government agencies in the implementation of the different, interrelated 
activities will be needed. The relatively weak capacity of government agencies to implement 
reforms  will  be  addressed  by  the  contributions  of  high-quality  international  consultants. 
Interagency coordination led by the executing agency will identify vested interests that may 
undermine policy reforms. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
18.  The TA is estimated to cost $1,000,000, of which $800,000 will be financed on a grant 
basis by ADB’s Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF-IV). The government will provide 
counterpart support in the form of counterpart staff, office and housing accommodation, office 
supplies, secretarial assistance, domestic transportation, and other in-kind contributions. Cost 
estimates and a financing plan are provided in Appendix 2. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
19.  Replicating earlier arrangements, the executing agency for the TA will be the  MPI. 
Implementing agencies include (i) the Central Institute for Economic Management (CIEM) for 
activities related to the review of the Enterprise Law; (ii) the Ministry of Justice for activities 
related to the provision of legal services to SMEs and the development of the SME portal; and 
(iii) Vietnam  Competition  Authority  (VCA)  for  the  review  of  the  Competition  Law  and  the 
preparation of the related RIA. The expected commencement date will be October 2012, and 
the TA will be completed by December 2013. Disbursements under the TA will be done in 
accordance with ADB’s Technical Assistance Disbursement Handbook (2010, as amended from 
time to time). As some activity costs will be administered by the executing agency, an advance 
payment facility will be used as in prior TA. The TA will employ consultants in a wide range of 
areas, including private sector financing and legal advisory assistance to SMEs. An outline of 
the terms of reference for the proposed consultants is in Appendix 3. The consultants will be 
engaged by ADB in accordance with the Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2010, as 
amended from time to time). Procurement of goods will be done in accordance with ADB’s 
Procurement Guidelines (2010, as amended from time to time). All equipment will be turned 
over to the EA at the end of the TA.

A.   International Consultants 
 
1.  Private  Sector  Development  Specialist  –  Financial  Services  for  Small  and 
Medium-Sized Enterprises (5 person-months) 
 
2.  The consultant will hold a graduate degree in economics, public policy, or other relevant 
discipline  for  the  assignment.  The  consultant  will  have  at  least  10  years  of  substantive 
experience in applied research, regulatory development, and policy implementation in the area 
of private sector development. The consultant will be familiar with private sector development 
challenges in Viet Nam and with relevant international experiences. Fluency in Vietnamese will 
be an asset and a successful record of assignments with the implementing agencies will be 
highly valued. The consultant will (i) design the structure and content of information systems 
required to provide access to financial services for small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) 
from the Agency for SME Development (ASMED) portal; (ii) design a business self-assessment 
tool for SMEs; (iii) develop operational guidelines for the SME Development Fund; and (iv) 
assist processing of the proposed program as necessary. The consultant will be assisted by a 
national expert who will provide support to the completion of all relevant tasks. 
 
2.  Private  Sector  Development  Specialist  –  Legal  Services  for  Small  and 
Medium-Sized Enterprises (3 person-months) 
 
 
3.  The  consultant  will  hold  a  graduate  degree  in  law,  public  policy,  or  other  relevant 
discipline  for  the  assignment.  The  consultant  will  have  at  least  10  years  of  substantive 
experience in institutional and capacity development for the delivery of legal services to the 
private sector. The consultant will be familiar with private sector development challenges in Viet 
Nam and with relevant international experiences. Fluency in Vietnamese will be an asset and a

successful record of assignments with the implementing agencies will be highly valued. The 
consultant  will  (i)  evaluate,  on  the  basis  of  international  best  practices,  the  institutional 
development of the SME Legal Support Department of the Ministry of Justice (MOJ) and identify 
best practices for sharing of experiences; (ii) assess information needs on access to legal 
documents and services from SMEs in Viet Nam and design an index of contents for the 
business  portal;  (iii) organize  and  implement  a  study  tour  as  a  learning  activity  for  the 
development of SME legal support services within the MOJ; and (iv) perform other tasks as 
requested by the program officer. The consultant will be assisted by a national expert who will 
provide support to the completion of all relevant tasks. 
 
3.         Public–Private Partnerships Specialist (1.5 person-months) 
 
4.  The consultant will hold a graduate degree in economics, public policy, or other relevant 
discipline  for  the  assignment.  The  consultant  will  have  at  least  15  years  of  substantive 
experience in the facilitation of public–private partnerships (PPPs) and the development of a 
regulatory  framework  for  such  ventures.  The  consultant  will  have  extensive  international 
experience in the development of PPPs in several sectors, and specific experience in the 
development of PPPs for SMEs. Fluency in Vietnamese will be an asset and a successful 
record of assignments with the implementing agencies will be highly valued. The consultant will 
(i)  assess  Viet  Nam’s  current  regulatory  framework  for  PPPs  and  benchmark  it  with  best 
international experiences; (ii) identify sector potential for the development of PPPs with SME 
participation; and (iii) outline proposals for the implementation of the policy recommendations. 
All the above-mentioned tasks will be incorporated in the consultant’s final report. 
 
4.  Corporate Governance Specialist (2 person-months)
 
 
5.  The  consultant  will  hold  a  graduate  degree  in  law,  public  policy,  or  other  relevant 
discipline  for  the  assignment.  The  consultant  will  have  at  least  10  years  of  substantive 
experience in the development of corporate governance policies and regulations in several 
countries. The consultant will offer experience in applied research, regulatory development, and 
policy implementation in the area of corporate governance for SMEs. The consultant will be 
familiar with private sector development challenges in Viet Nam and with relevant international 
experiences. Fluency in Vietnamese will be an asset and a successful record of assignments 
with  the  implementing  agencies  will  be  highly  valued.  The  consultant  will  (i)  research 
international  experience  in  the  development  of  corporate  governance  and  mergers  and 
acquisitions provisions in the amended Enterprise Law; (ii) prepare recommendations for the 
amendment of the law; and (iii) discuss and lead dialogue with relevant counterparts. 
 
5.  Competition Law Expert (2 person-months) 
 
6.  The  consultant  will  hold  a  graduate  degree  in  law,  public  policy,  or  other  relevant 
discipline  for  the  assignment.  The  consultant  will  have  at  least  10  years  of  substantive 
experience in the development and evaluation of competition law in several countries. The 
consultant will also have experience in applied research, regulatory development, and policy 
implementation in the area of competition policy and law. The consultant will be familiar with 
private sector development challenges in Viet Nam and with relevant international experiences. 
Fluency  in  Vietnamese  will  be  an  asset  and a  successful  record  of assignments  with the 
implementing agencies will be highly valued. The consultant will (i) assist the review of the 
competition law and related regulations; and (ii) prepare a draft regulatory impact assessment 
aligned with government guidelines and manuals. The consultant will be assisted by a national 
expert who will provide support to the completion of all relevant tasks.

7.  The consultants will hold a degree in business administration, law, economics, or other 
relevant discipline for the assignment. The consultants will have at least 8 years of substantive 
experience in the domestic private sector, in particular, dealing with financial aspects related to 
the development of SMEs. The consultants will also have experience in applied research, 
regulatory  development,  and  policy  implementation  for  private  sector  development.  The

to the development of the operational guidelines for the SME Development Fund; and (iv) any 
other related tasks as instructed by the executing agency.  
 
2.  Legal Expert (7 person-months) 
 
8.  The consultant will hold a degree in law, business administration, or other relevant 
discipline  for  the  assignment.  The  consultant  will  have  at  least  10  years  of  substantive 
experience  in  SME  development.  The  consultant  will  have  relevant  experience  in  applied 
research, regulatory development, and policy implementation for private sector development 
reforms. The consultant will be familiar with private sector development challenges in Viet Nam 
and with relevant international experiences. Fluency in English and Vietnamese is required and 
a successful record of assignments with the implementing agencies will be highly valued. The 
consultant, guided by the implementing agencies, will prepare the regulatory impact assessment 
for the revised Competition Law and the revised Enterprise Law. The consultant will follow 
national guidelines for the preparation of regulatory impact assessments and will work closely 
with the competition law expert and the corporate governance specialist.

aspects  of  SME  development.  The  consultant  will  offer  experience  in  applied  research, 
regulatory  development,  and  policy  implementation  for  financial  reform  and  private  sector 
development. The consultant will be familiar with private sector development challenges in Viet 
Nam and with relevant international experiences. Fluency in English and Vietnamese is required 
and a successful record of assignments with the implementing agencies will be highly valued.

operational guidelines for the forthcoming SME Development Fund, (ii) assist the drafting of the 
SME law, and (iii) perform other related tasks as instructed by the executing agency.
